Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Legal Barriers to Securing the Routing Architecture

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
IP addresses can be stolen or hijacked. It can happen instantly, and may result in a loss of Internet connectivity and/or diversion of traffic to a malicious entity. Until recently, an organization was unable to prove ownership of its Internet address. A global Resource Public Key Infrastructure (RPKI) is a framework designed to secure the Internet's routing infrastructure by enabling Third parties to cryptographically validate claims of ownership of Internet address blocks and permit such resource holders to declare routing relationships. However, adoption of RPKI remains at an impasse largely due to legal factors. This project supports an independent assessment of the proper allocation of liability for uses of RPKI by related parties, such as network operators, that can serve as the basis for the parties to discuss resolving the impasse over the indemnification clauses in the Relaying Party Agreement (RPA). If those discussions are successful, the research will ultimately promote more widespread use of RPKI in North America and enable a more secure Internet.

BGP is a live distributed protocol which spans the globe, operating on millions of routers, interconnecting 60,000 distinct administrative domains, called Autonomous Systems (AS), and providing routing information to 700,000 destination networks. BGP was originally designed in an era in which security was not a significant concern, and major BGP route changes were communicated by operators via email or community mailing lists. However, the Internet has grown exponentially and the systemic vulnerabilities of the global BGP routing system have been the subject of concern for network operators for the last decade. RPKI provides one solution to the problem. One of the largest obstacles to the adoption of RPKI to secure BGP routing, however, is the fact that most organizations will not or cannot sign ARIN's RPKI Relying Agreement. By conducting a legal analysis and enabling a new form of agreement and compromise, progress forward can be made on this important underlying component of the Internet infrastructure.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research supported by this NSF EAGER grant was designed with three major goals in mind.

First, the project sought to identify possible legal barriers impeding the deployment a promising framework for securing Internet routing known as the Resource Public Key Infrastructure ("RPKI"). RPKI enables the autonomous systems ("ASes") comprising the global Internet to validate the origins of the routes in their routing tables.  Although adoption of the RPKI framework has been slow worldwide, it has been particularly slow in North America. Prior to the inauguration of this project, many participants in the network engineering field (including academics and practitioners) held the view that legal issues were stymying adoption of RPKI in North America. In response to these widely held (but inchoate and untested) views, this project had the goal of identifying and independently assessing all material legal barriers to RPKI adoption.  

Second, the project was designed to produce actionable recommendations to support the deployment of RPKI, especially in North America. The project was meant to be a "translational" contribution to the field of network engineering. It was meant to enable the Internet security community to better understand and overcome the legal issues that are holding back the adoption of a promising and valuable technological framework.

Third, the project was designed to generate contributions to academic theory on the role of law in supporting the development and diffusion of innovative technology. Specifically, the project proposed to shed light on how contractual relationships and corporate organizational structures can help or hinder the adoption of new technology within the global Internet. 

Initially, to deliver on these goals, the team successfully canvassed the field of network engineering to identify all potentially significant legal barriers to the adoption of the RPKI framework. The team interviewed practicing engineers and academics alike. Through conversations with both groups, the research team learned that the set of perceived barriers to RPKI was broader than had originally been identified in public dialogue. The team's interview research also revealed that many network engineers disagreed with each other about the nature of the barriers to RPKI adoption and the significance of legal issues generally. The team also analyzed the relevant contracts and evaluated the relevant case law.

The team's independent analysis produced useful results for the network engineering community. The team's analysis offered network engineers a perspective on the problem of RPKI non-adoption that transcended water-cooler chatter or individual statements made at professional conferences. It helped identify which barriers really were salient across the entire community, and it revealed that some of the perceived legal barriers to RPKI adoption were based on misunderstandings. Most importantly, the team developed a set of actionable recommendations for the American Registry of Internet Numbers ("ARIN"), which operates the RPKI repository for North America, and for the larger networking community. These recommendations have become central aspects of ongoing dialogue between ARIN and its members regarding reform of the RPKI legal framework. ARIN has already adopted one of the recommendations that had been part of a circulating draft of the team's report and has publicly committed itself to consider and respond to the team's final report during 2019.

In addition to practical impact, the project has yielded useful results at the level of academic theory. The research conducted under this grant shed light on the dynamics of technology adoption in the Internet setting. Many new technologies--especially security technologies--present what is often referred to as a "chicken-and-egg" problem. This is a type of collective action problem where large benefits accrue to community members if large numbers of network operators adopt a new technology, but early adopters do not have strong immediate incentives to adopt. The challenge in these situations is to move towards the valuable state of widespread adoption. This project's research reveals that nonprofits like ARIN and the North American Network Operators Group ("NANOG") have important roles to play in promoting adoption, as do early first movers who identify themselves to a broader community to create excitement about a new technology. The research further reveals that the professional incentives of individual people within large organizations can help shape adoption decisions. These results suggest future avenues for research in economics, law, and sociology regarding technology adoption patterns in settings like the global Internet.
